item.title: Ghost Factories Are a Warning Sign for Green Manufacturing’s Future
item.description: Rollbacks of clean-energy credits in Trump’s tax bill add to the sector’s challenges as project cancellations rise.

item.title: Charting the Global Economy: US Jobs Data Eases Pressure on Fed
item.description: Fresh US jobs figures took pressure off the Federal Reserve to consider an interest-rate cut later this month, likely leaving the central bank on hold at least until the fall.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle

media:content.media:description: Recruiters and job seekers speak during a job fair hosted by the Cook County government to support federal workers in Chicago, Illinois, US, on Thursday, June 26, 2025. Thousands of private government consultants laid off during the Trump administration's cost-cutting crusade are increasingly flooding a shrinking labor market.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Strikes Air Base in Russia’s Voronezh Region
item.description: Ukraine’s military said its special forces struck the Borysoglebsk airfield in Russia’s Voronezh region as Kyiv continues to look for ways to reduce the Kremlin’s ability to conduct airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Olesia Safronova

item.title: Turkey Detains Three Mayors in Widening Probe, Anadolu Reports
item.description: Turkish police detained the mayors of three cities and a number of other officials, the state-run Anadolu Agency reported, in an escalation of a probe into municipalities governed by the opposition Republican People’s Party, or CHP.
item.dc:creator: Tugce Ozsoy

media:content.media:description: A Turkish national flag, left, and a flag bearing the portrait of Kemal Ataturk, founder of the modern Turkish republic, hang from the exterior of a building in the Sisli district of Istanbul, Turkey, on Monday, Aug. 29, 2022. Turkey’s central bank delivered a shock cut to interest rates despite inflation soaring to a 24-year high and the lira trading near a record low. Photographer: Nicole Tung/Bloomberg

item.title: BlackRock Halted Ukraine Fund Talks After Trump’s Election Win
item.description: BlackRock Inc. halted its search for investors to back a multibillion-dollar Ukraine recovery fund earlier this year after Donald Trump’s election victory saw the US sour on the eastern European country, people familiar with the discussions said.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard, Donato Paolo Mancini, Leonard Kehnscherper

media:content.media:description: BlackRock headquarters in New York, US, on Tuesday, April 8, 2025. Blackrock Inc. is scheduled to release earnings figures on April 11. Photographer: Bing Guan/Bloomberg

item.title: Hamas Says It’s Ready to ‘Immediately’ Enter Ceasefire Talks
item.description: Hamas said it is ready to “immediately” start negotiations with Israel on a proposal by US President Donald Trump for a 60-day ceasefire in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Fares Alghoul, Shamim Adam

media:content.media:description: This picture taken from a position at Israel's border with the Gaza Strip shows smoke billowing during an Israeli strike on the besieged Palestinian territory on July 3, 2025, amid the ongoing war between Israel and the Hamas Islamist militant group. item.title: Starmer Has Nowhere to Go, Stuck Between Rebels and Bond Market
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer is caught between a political rebellion and a jittery bond market.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Philip Aldrick, Greg Ritchie

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer, right, and Rachel Reeves in London on July 3. Photographer: Jack Hill/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Death Count Climbs in Texas After Severe Flooding
item.description: KERRVILLE, Texas (AP) — Months worth of heavy rain fell in a matter of hours on Texas Hill Country, leaving 24 people dead and many more unaccounted for Friday, including more than 20 girls attending a summer camp, as search teams conducted boat and helicopter rescues in fast-moving floodwaters.

media:content.media:description: Fallen trees and debris in the Guadalupe River in Kerrville, Texas, on July 4. Photographer: Eric Gay/AP Photo

item.title: China Can Work With France Over Range of Sectors, Wang Says
item.description: China is ready to cooperate with France in industries such as nuclear power, aviation, artificial intelligence, green energy and biotechnology, Foreign Minister Wang Yi said.
item.dc:creator: Samy Adghirni, Li Liu

media:content.media:description: Jean-Noel Barrot, right, and Wang Yi arrive for a news conference in Paris on July 4. Photographer: Aurelien Morissard/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Vietnam Gains Edge With Early Trump Deal, US Group Head Says
item.description: Vietnam’s race to secure a trade deal with the Trump administration, even if the details aren’t clear, gives the Southeast Asian country an advantage over regional rivals, according to Ted Osius, president of the US-Asean Business Council.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Stevens, Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen

item.title: Hamas Says It’s Ready to Negotiate Ceasefire Proposal, More Talks Needed
item.description: DEIR al-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) — Hamas said Friday it has given a “positive” response to the latest proposal for a ceasefire in Gaza but said further talks were needed on implementation.

media:content.media:description: A resident inspects the damage after an Israeli strike in the Al-Bureij camp in the central Gaza Strip on July 4. Photographer: Eyad Baba/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Reeves Tells Cabinet Next Tax Rise to Be Challenging, Times Says
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves told cabinet ministers that tax increases in the Labour government’s fall budget are likely to be even more challenging than a £40 billion ($55 billion) ­package she put in place last year, the Times reported.
item.dc:creator: Tony Czuczka

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves, UK chancellor of the exchequer, arrives for a news conference ahead of the publication of the government's immigration white paper, in London, UK, on Monday, May 12, 2025. The UK will increase English-speaking requirements for migrants, and make it harder for them to stay in the country as part of efforts to rein in levels of net immigration that have touched records in recent years.

item.title: Trump Signs His Tax-and-Spend Bill at White House Ceremony
item.description: President Donald Trump signed his $3.4 trillion budget bill into law Friday, enshrining an extension of tax cuts, temporary new breaks for tipped workers and funding to crack down on illegal immigration.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump displays the signed bill during a ceremony for the One Big Beautiful Bill Act on the South Lawn of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, July 4, 2025. Trump signed his $3.4 trillion budget bill into law Friday, enshrining an extension of tax cuts, temporary new breaks for tipped workers and funding to crack down on illegal immigration.

item.title: Cocaine Boom and Rising Violence Push US to Reassess Colombia
item.description: Rising tensions between the US and Colombia suggest Donald Trump’s administration is upping the pressure on the Andean nation ahead of a decision on its certification in the fight against illegal drugs.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Jaramillo, Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: A farmer at a coca plantation in Argelia, Cauca department, Colombia, in May.

item.title: Spotify Accused by Turkish Official of ‘Insulting’ Content
item.description: A Turkish official called for legal action against Spotify Technologies SA, saying the streaming service’s content isn’t in accord with the nation’s cultural and moral values.
item.dc:creator: Tugce Ozsoy

media:content.media:description: The Spotify logo on a smartphone arranged in Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands, on Saturday, Jan. 29, 2022. Spotify Technology SA outlined steps it will take to halt the spread of misleading information about Covid-19 on its audio-streaming service in an attempt to quell a growing controversy over its support for the podcast host Joe Rogan. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

item.title: BRICS Set to Condemn ‘Coercive’ Tariffs, Draft Statement Shows
item.description: BRICS leaders are poised to adopt a position at odds with US President Donald Trump on trade tariffs, aspects of conflict in the Middle East and the need to tackle climate change.
item.dc:creator: Mirette Magdy, S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: Signage for the BRICS summit 2025 in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil on July 4.

item.title: EU-US Trade Talks Focus on Tariff Offset for Automakers
item.description: Some European Union carmakers and capitals are pushing for an agreement with President Donald Trump that would allow for tariff relief in return for increasing investment in the US, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: The quality control area of VW ID.3 compact hatchback electric automobile production line at the Volkswagen AG factory in Dresden, Germany, on Wednesday, May 14, 2025. Volkswagen and other EV makers appear to be benefiting from consumers’ aversion to Tesla after Elon Musk became more involved in US President Donald Trump’s administration and supported far-right political movements in Europe, such as Germany’s AfD party.

item.title: BRICS Aspires to Occupy Ground Vacated by US Under Trump
item.description: Ever since BRICS was founded more than a decade ago, the group of emerging-market nations has struggled to identify a common purpose. President Donald Trump’s tariffs may have solved that problem.

item.title: Slovenian Lawmakers Back Referendum on Defense Spending Plans
item.description: Slovenian lawmakers approved a motion to hold a referendum on increasing defense spending, a move that could thwart government plans to join the rest of Europe in bolstering security.

item.description: US President Donald Trump said his administration will probably start notifying trading partners Friday of the new US tariff on their exports effective Aug. 1, while reiterating a preference for simplicity over complicated negotiations five days before his deadline for deals.

item.title: Total Edges Closer to Restart Work on $20 Billion Mozambique LNG
item.description: Companies hired by TotalEnergies SE to build a $20 billion gas project in northern Mozambique have started preparing to resume work on the venture, four years after it was suspended because of a militant insurgency, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Henrique Almeida, Paul Burkhardt

item.title: Vandals, Maintenance Missteps Leave Swaths of Johannesburg Dry
item.description: Large parts of Johannesburg, South Africa’s biggest city, have been without water since late last month as reservoirs struggle to recover from scheduled maintenance and after criminals vandalized a key pipeline.
item.dc:creator: Antony Sguazzin

item.description: Rwandan President Paul Kagame praised the US role in orchestrating a peace deal with the Democratic Republic of Congo and promised that his country would implement its side of the bargain.

item.title: Zelenskiy Says He Agreed to Work With Trump to Boost Air Defense
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said he and Donald Trump agreed to cooperate on air defense as the Ukrainian leader sought to press Washington to resume key weapons deliveries.

item.title: Germany in Talks With US to Get Patriot Air Defense for Kyiv
item.description: Germany is in advanced talks with the US to secure at least two additional Patriot air-defense systems for Ukraine as Russia steps up its drone and missile attacks and Washington places a hold on weapons deliveries this week.

item.description: NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte said he was hoping for US “flexibility” so Ukraine has the resources to defend itself after Washington unexpectedly halted some deliveries due to concerns that its stockpiles had fallen too low.

item.title: US-Swiss Trade Deal Likely to Contain Assurances on Pharma Levy
item.description: The draft of a trade accord between the US and Switzerland contains a provision that the European country will receive preferred treatment in the ongoing national-security investigations to avoid tariffs on pharma exports, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright, Jenny Leonard

item.title: US Plans AI Chip Curbs on Malaysia, Thailand Over China Concerns
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration plans to restrict shipments of AI chips from the likes of Nvidia Corp. to Malaysia and Thailand, part of an effort to crack down on suspected semiconductor smuggling into China.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins

item.title: Harvard Warns Foreign Students Over US Airport, Social Media
item.description: Harvard University staff advised international students to be cautious about social media posts and warned some groups against arriving at Boston’s Logan International Airport.
item.dc:creator: Anika Arora Seth, Emma Haidar, Brunella Tipismana Urbano

media:content.media:description: The Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US, on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. Harvard University won a longer-term reprieve from a Trump administration ban on enrolling international students, handing the nations oldest and richest university a victory in its battle with the White House.
